question: To some guys, women are like a cheap puzzle... with pieces that just don't fit. They think the soul of a woman is darker than a back alley... more tangled than a telephone cord... and colder than a Klondike Bar in Canada. But those guys don't even have a clue. When you know women the way I do, you understand exactly what what makes them tick... what makes them hum... what makes them jiggle up and down when they walk. And it's not the kind of thing you can learn from a correspondence course. There are two kinds of women in this world... and I've known 'em both. One will take you for a fast ride on a bumpy road with no seat belt. But the other kind...
answer: Jeez... knock off the chatter, will ya.

question: Just trying to keep you awake, Arch.
answer: I'm awake! Where do you come up with all that crap about women?

question: It's true. Women are very complex, but if you know how to read 'em... they're an open book. You can always tell the rotten apples from the peaches.
answer: Are you kiddin'?

question: I'd stake my career on it. Anybody ever proves me wrong, I'll throw away my badge.
answer: Aayyhh... women are trouble...

question: I used to believe that too. Until I married Lana. Now, she... is a peach.
answer: Yeah, well you're a lucky stiff, pal. Ya hold down two jobs. Got a beautiful wife waitin' for ya at home. Everything a guy could ever want, including NO kids.

question: I'd love to have kids.
answer: What?! Rug-rats? Give me a break! Jeez, I hate stakeouts. What makes you think Milo's gonna show up here?

question: Logic. He knocked off all those banks. He's got cash. He's gonna want to spend it. This is one of the few places that still takes cash. Sooner or later... he's gotta turn up.
answer: And how we s'posed to recognize this scumbag?

question: The "Support Hose Bandit"? When you see him... you'll know him.
answer: These are the best damn Nachos in North America. Maybe the world! I'm empty. I'm gonna get a refill. You want some?

question: Got a light?
answer: Sure.

question: How about a match?
answer: No thanks. I have plenty.

question: You really are incredibly stupid, aren't you? I like that in a man.
answer: I'd be insulted, but I know you're serious.

question: You sound so sure of yourself.
answer: I'm not as dumb as I look.

question: Let me buy you a drink, Mr. uh...
answer: Ravine. Ned Ravine. And you are...?

question: Thirsty. What about that drink?
answer: I'm on duty.

question: Brain surgeon?
answer: Cop.

question: Oooo... and I bet you have a big gun.
answer: You lose.

question: If I can't buy you a drink... ...let me buy you one of those.
answer: Who can say no to a weiner?

question: Not me. Two dogs. Hot.
answer: You come here often?

question: Only when I'm in heat.
answer: Oh! Sorry.

question: Where ya going?
answer: Get something to wipe it off.

question: That's okay. You're doing just fine.
answer: I'll get you a wet paper towel. Hold it right there, Milo! Police emergency! I need your car!

question: You take science in high school, Milo?
answer: I skipped high school, cop!

question: Then you're probably not familiar with the theory of inverse proportionate explosive dynamics.
answer: What about it?

question: If you fire a weapon with the barrel obstructed, the explosive force multiplies by twenty-three point five nine eight and reverses on itself with diametric polarity?
answer: Yeah. So?

question: The gun will blow up in your hand... and it won't even scorch my pinkie.
answer: Ha! That's just theoretical hypothesis. Inverse proportionate explosive dynamics has never been demonstrated conclusively in a laboratory environment.

question: Oh yeah. Then pull the trigger, smart guy. Let's find out. You have the right to remain silent... next... if you waive that right, anything you say... next... ...may be used against you in a court of law... next... You have the right to an attorney... Do you have an attorney?
answer: Nahhhh!

question: Oh yes, Frank! Adjust the stroke by ten percent! That's it. Now tweak my points. Oh yes, oh yes! You got it! Stabilize your ball joints and grind my rear differential! Now accelerate! Floor it! Lay rubber, baby! VRRROOOOOOOOOOMMMMMMMMM! Not bad for an auto mechanic...
answer: Yeah, well you're not so bad yourself... for a lawyer's wife...

question: Better watch your tongue, sweetie, or I'll have my husband arrest you.
answer: Busy man. Cop and a lawyer. When does he ever find time for you?

question: He doesn't. That's why I need you to keep my engine tuned, Frank. Why drive a jalopy when you can have a hot rod?
answer: Maybe you should trade him in on a new model.

question: I would... if I could make any money on the deal.
answer: Want to go for another test drive?

question: Pull over and park it, Frank. I'm still under warranty.
answer: Morning sweetheart.

question: Uh huh. Want some coffee?
answer: No thanks.

question: Frank here was just grabbing a little before going back to work on my car.
answer: How long you been working on Lana's Mercedes, Frank?

question: How long you been working on Lana's Mercedes, Frank?
answer: Oh... I don't know... six, seven weeks.

question: And ya still haven't found the problem?
answer: Think I got my finger on it though.

question: Laura... do you know where...?
answer: Right here. The judge decided to skip arraignment and take Milo direct to trial. You're six minutes late, but don't sweat it. You got Judge Allen. He's always eleven minutes late. I suggest you try Lemming versus Florida, 1956... where the guy jumped in the water and everybody followed.

question: Yeah. Good idea. I don't know what I'd do without you?
answer: Really?

question: Laura, how long have you worked for me?
answer: Two years, seven months, twenty-three days, nineteen hours... ...six minutes and fifty-two seconds. ...fifty-three... fifty-four... fifty- five... fifty-six...

question: And when was the last time I gave you a raise?
answer: Never. But that's okay. I don't need a raise. In fact... I was thinking of giving you a rebate on my salary.

question: Laura. Laura! What is it?
answer: I'm okay, I'm okay. I just get a bit... claustrophobic... in the bathroom.

question: Maybe we should try some prune juice.
answer: Wear the blue one.

question: Ladies and gentlemen... I ask you... does this look like the face of a crook? Of course it does. But the question of my client's guilt or innocence is not the issue here today. I'm certain every member of the jury can clearly see that he's guilty! Put yourself in his shoes. Look through his eyes. See the world the way HE sees it! Things just don't look the same. It's fuzzy... and frightening! Ladies and gentlemen... Milo Crumley is not the perpetrator here. He is the VICTIM! Like ALL of us... this man is the unfortunate victim of these tragically difficult economic times. And what does that mean? He can't support his family! For God's sake!... He can't even support his own FACE!
answer: Mr. Crumley... you cannot chew gum in my courtroom... unless you have enough for everyone. Bailiff. Pass these out. And don't forget the jury.

question: And so, desperate and broke, with no other options before him, Mr. Crumley went to eleven Savings & Loans and did what any of you would have done. He stole back the money that the S&Ls had stolen from him!
answer: Mr. Ravine... please approach the bench. You're not running for congress here, so knock off the speeches and quit inciting these brainless morons! Now pick up the pace and wrap this son- of-a-bitch up! Call your first witness.

question: pushes the door open. It's Lola. She wears a tight white dress, long white gloves and broad-brimmed hat. The hat tips up slowly, revealing her eyes.
answer: I waited. You never came back.

question: I got busy. Here's that paper towel I promised.
answer: Thanks...

question: How'd you get in? The door was locked.
answer: It's miraculous what a real woman can do... with a bobbie pin. Cigarette?

question: No... thanks. They're bad for ya.
answer: Yes, I know. I like things that are bad for me. So... I hear you go both ways.

question: Only once. It was a fraternity prank. I never saw him again.
answer: No, I mean... you're a cop and a lawyer.

question: Gotta keep these darn books in their right place or we'll never find the ones we need. Let's see, Q thru M... R thru B... W thru F...
answer: It's getting late. I'll give you a ride home, Ned.

question: I have my car.
answer: I'll tow you.

question: Not today. You don't need to wait. I'll see you tomorrow.
answer: I should call someone to fix this...

question: Tomorrow...
answer: I'll call from home.

question: I think I should warn you, Mr. Ravine... I'm not wearing any underwear.
answer: Try these on. So... what can I do for you?

question: I've run across some... papers... and I thought you might be able to tell me what they are. You see, I'm not very experienced when it comes to... papers.
answer: I'll help you Miss Cain, if I'm able. Do you have the... papers... here?

question: No... they're at home. I thought you might stop by...
answer: I'm on duty tonight.

question: Don't they ever give you a night off?
answer: Yeah. Tomorrow.

question: Why don't we meet tomorrow evening then? I'll let you know where.
answer: What's wrong with my office?

question: I came back for my shower cap.
answer: Yeah, well you came to the right place. Sit down.

question: Where is he?
answer: On duty all night. By the time he wraps up his reports, it'll be close to noon tomorrow. I was just reading over... Take off the hat, Frank. I was just reading over my husband's insurance policies. You wouldn't know anything about insurance, would you, Frankie?

question: Yeah, matter of fact, I sell policies part-time. I got half a brain... or didn't you notice?
answer: I musta had my eye on something else. How about a translation.

question: Standard accident policy... all the usual stuff... blah, blah, blah. The face value is... Wow. Not bad. Three million bucks! And there's a triple indemnity rider.
answer: Meaning?

question: Aw, it's just something agents throw in so we can boost the premium. If the policy holder dies under very specific conditions, it pays off three times the face value of the policy.
answer: Nine million dollars...?

question: Yeah... but it's a sure bet for the company. Nobody ever collects.
answer: Why not?

question: Well, like here... it only pays off if he's shot with a pistol, falls from a moving northbound train and drowns in a fresh water stream.
answer: All three?

question: See what I mean, sweetheart? What are the odds of that?
answer: It could happen. Suppose it did happen?

question: Then you'd be rich.
answer: Then we'd be rich.

question: What're you sayin'...?
answer: We're gonna kill the son-of-a-bitch! And I know exactly how! He has a legal symposium in Santa Barbara this weekend... All we have to do is get him to take the train up instead of driving.

question: How we gonna do that? Didn't you tell me he hates trains?
answer: That's where you come in, baby. You're gonna rig his car so it doesn't work. That should be no problem for you. Then... we give him a lift to the train station... through Dealey Plaza, past the Book Suppository and around the grassy knoll...

question: Isn't that out of our way?
answer: Move, Frank. And pay attention. Ten minutes out of the station he'll be standing in the vestibule between cars... trying to avoid a panic attack. Fourteen minutes and ten seconds out, the train crosses the Santa Ynez River. So at thirteen minutes and fifty-four seconds, I shoot him, shove him out the door... he hits the river and drowns. Bingo! A triple play. We're rich!

question: You been thinking about this a lot, haven't you?
answer: No. It just came to me. I had this image of a big, powerful, throbbing train... plunging into a long, dark, wet tunnel.

question: Damn birds!
answer: My God, Ned... you look like you were hit by a bus.

question: I was. Who's in my office?
answer: Max Shady's mother.

question: Not again. Hello, Mrs. Shady. Laura... check on my insurance. Make sure it's paid up.
answer: Good idea, Mr. Ravine. My son, Max, is getting out of prison tomorrow.

question: Gee, has it been seven years already?
answer: Seven long, miserable years in the slammer. And he's a bit pissed off.

question: Well, being locked in a tiny room with no TV can make a guy feel pretty tense.
answer: I'm very concerned about him, Mr. Ravine. He said you were a two-bit shyster... and he's going to rip your head off and use it for a bowling ball!

question: I'm sure the experience wasn't all negative. He probably made a lot of friends...
answer: You think?

question: ...learned a useful trade...
answer: Oh yes... live autopsies...

question: ...caught up on all those books he wanted to read...
answer: Maybe so... but he said he's going to punch you in the testicles... ...smash your face... ...and decimate your wardrobe. And I wouldn't want that to happen. He's a naughty naughty boy. I just thought I should warn you. Bye for now. Oh... may I have a cookie?

question: Oh my God, Ned.
answer: I hate when she comes to see me.

question: Don't you realize, Ned?... you could be in real danger.
answer: What's that?

question: Extreme peril. You know, the risk of personal bodily harm.
answer: No... I mean that.

question: Your insurance file. But the policy's missing. Did you take it home?
answer: I don't think so.

question: Oh yeah, before I forget... you asked me to take care of this.
answer: Thanks...

question: You smoke too much. It's hot tonight.
answer: Is it? I never know. My body heat runs about twenty degrees above normal.

question: Maybe we should look for a cooler place.
answer: I doubt we'll find one. Even the wind chimes on my porch aren't moving much these days. They keep thudding softly, like dairy cows bumping butts in the night. I go out there expecting to find a cool breeze... but it's just a lot of hot air.

question: What're they lookin' at?
answer: A lot of them have tried that seat. You're the first one's lasted this long.

question: I feel honored.
answer: Don't. It's broken.

question: Did you bring the... papers?
answer: No. I thought you might come over...

question: Sure. I'll drive you.
answer: I brought my own car.

question: I'll follow you then.
answer: I know it sounds silly, but would you leave first... wait in your car? I come here a lot and I wouldn't want those men to think I'm "easy"... a slut who'll jump into bed with anyone at the drop of a hat. But if you leave first...

question: ...they'll think I'm a putz for passing up a sure thing.
answer: Now leave me alone!

question: Well, here we are... in the dark.
answer: I have The Clapper.

question: You what?
answer: My wind chimes.

question: You know, these would work a lot better if you took them out of the boxes.
answer: Well well... I guess you have been around. I'm impressed.

question: Why don't we take a look at those... papers?
answer: Papers. Right.

question: That's it? These are the... papers?
answer: Yes. They're so confusing to me. Can you tell me what they are?

question: This one's a laundry receipt... and the other one's an expired lottery ticket.
answer: No. You keep them... as a memento of our time together. I'm so grateful. How can I ever repay you for all you've done?

question: Cash would be nice.
answer: Isn't there some other way?

question: I suppose you could wash my car.
answer: No, I mean, isn't there something else you want? Something I could give you?

question: Hey... slow down... there's a speed limit in this state. Sixty-five miles an hour.
answer: How fast was I going, officer?

question: Oh, about a hundred and twenty-three.
answer: Suppose you pull me over and frisk me?

question: Suppose I let you off with a warning?
answer: Suppose I find a cop with a bigger nightstick?

question: Suppose I put you under arrest for being a bad girl with bad thoughts?
answer: Suppose you handcuff me to the bed?

question: Suppose I do and then we lose the key and while I'm gone to get a duplicate made the house catches on fire and I can't get back to save you because the bridge is washed out and so you die a horrible death toasted like a Polish sausage on a flaming spit! Nah... I better be going.
answer: You're not so tough. Last chance.

question: No thanks. I got a cold shower and a wife who trusts me waiting at home.
answer: What's the matter? Don't you want me? It's the way I look, isn't it?

question: Don't forget to lock up.
answer: I knew you'd come back...

question: I forgot my car keys.
answer: That's not what you came back for.

question: That's Madam Butterfly, isn't it?
answer: Iron Butterfly. In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida.

question: Oh yeah, sure... now I can hear it.
answer: It tells the sad story of a woman who is rejected by her lover after a brief, but torrid, affair... so she stalks him with an ice pick and stabs him with it more than a thousand times.

question: Really? I never could understand the lyrics. You know, what happened last night was very, uh...
answer: Yes... it was. I should check on my homeowners insurance.

question: But we can't ever let it happen again. Ever!
answer: What are you saying, Ned? That you're rejecting me, your lover, after a brief, but torrid, affair?!

question: I wouldn't put it exactly like that. It's just that... well, I'm married to a wonderful woman... who is very, very attractive... ...not that you aren't very attractive! ...you aren't very attractive... you aren't very attractive... you aren't very attractive...
answer: Don't touch anything. You bond with it... you buy it. Whatdya want?

question: I'd like to buy a pet.
answer: Yeah. For what purpose?

question: It's a gift... for my wife.
answer: Right. They all say that.

question: She spends a lot of time alone. I thought it might be nice if she had something to keep her company.
answer: Yeah. Sure. I bet. How do I know you're not the kind of guy who punches out parakeets? Or takes some poor defenseless animal, throws it in a sack and runs over it with your car five or six times.

question: I would never hurt an animal.
answer: Boy, I would. They're driving me CRAZY! Shuddup! Okay... tell me more about this broad you're married to. I like to match people with the pets they deserve.

question: Trust me, I spent a lot of time with him when I was preparing his case. He's really a very sweet, sensitive human being.
answer: I'd like to mash his head like a ripe melon...

question: He gets a little melon-dramatic.
answer: ...then cut off all his fingers and rip out his liver with my teeth!

question: How come we gotta meet here?
answer: We have to be careful now. We can't risk being seen together at the house or someone might connect us to the murder later on. Here... put this on. Speak Yiddish.

question: What?
answer: Red Yiddish.

question: Ich hobe getracht, efsher iz der nisht geshtoigen un nisht gefloygen.
answer: Zein nisht azoy meshige! Der plan iz kosher vi yosher.

question: Yo! Ober mir darfen imvarfen in tsug. Un schissen un schtippen in vasser arein. Oy a broch! Mir zenen git bakackt.
answer: Vus iz mit idr? Die host a vaichen schmoke?

question: Ven hob ich gehat a vaichen schmoke?
answer: Lest'n Yomkippur.

question: Nu shoin, ein mul. Es paseert tsie yeyden man. Oy! Mir vellen zein oif groise tsures. Me'vet unz chap'n.
answer: You speak Yiddish?

question: Oh gee, you shouldn't have...
answer: I didn't. It's for my wife.

question: She called. Wondered why you never came home last night. I told her you were working with a client, undercover. Were you?
answer: What?

question: There's lipstick on your collar.
answer: No there isn't.

question: No... there isn't. But you answered my question. She's a real looker, huh?
answer: Who?

question: Lola Cain.
answer: I hadn't noticed.

question: Yeah, I noticed how you hadn't noticed. That's alright. She noticed enough for both of us. I worry about you, Ned. I worry a lot. Max Shady's been faxing death threats to you all morning.
answer: ...stick a knife in your... ...rip the eyeballs out of your... ...drive razor-sharp spikes under your...

question: Did you get to the one...?
answer: ...cut it off... shove it in a blender.

question: Yeah... that one.
answer: He's just getting it out of his system. Once they say it... they never do it. You know... like the President.

question: Wait. It might be him.
answer: Where did you get that?

question: From my purse.
answer: What are you doing with it?

question: Handing it to you.
answer: Jeez, Laura, what do you use a gun for?

question: You shoot it. A bullet comes out. Gosh, Ned, after all your years as a cop, I'd think you'd know these things.
answer: Laura... put the gun away.

question: Is this another sick joke from Max Shady?
answer: What is it...?

question: What happened to you last night?
answer: Why? What have you heard?

question: You could have called. But then, I suppose you were tied up.
answer: Only part of the time.

question: I never know when you're coming home, Ned. How can I ever make any plans?
answer: I promise I'll spend more time with you. I know it's been rough, being alone so much. But I'll make it up to you. Maybe we should try again, you know... to have a baby.

question: So what's in the box?
answer: Oh... I brought you a present!

question: What is it?
answer: It's... sorta like a cat.

question: Not enough like a cat.
answer: It's a little skunk. I got it at Birds-and-Skunks-R-Us. So... what're you going to name him?

question: How about... Ned?
answer: Yeah. Got a nice ring to it. I've always liked the name Ned.

question: No kidding.
answer: So whatdya think? You love Ned Junior as much as you love me?

question: Who's Frank?
answer: Frank? The only Frank I know is an auto mechanic... but I sure as hell wouldn't recommend the guy. He's really slow.

question: I had to see you, Ned. I need to feel your arms around me! I wanna suck your toes til the nails pop off!
answer: I told you, what happened was a big mistake. A one night stand. It's over. I have a wife...

question: It doesn't matter. She'll know all about us soon anyway. I want YOU! In my bed... in my arms... in MEEEEEEE! I got us tickets to see Iron Butterfly!
answer: I hate opera!

question: Why are you running from me? Didn't it mean ANYTHING to you?... buffing my buns with carnuba wax? Come on, Neddy-poo. Doesn't Mr. Pokey want to go exploring?
answer: He's busy right now. Look, I told you... Mr. Pokey made a big mistake! One lousy mistake in his whole stinkin' life! So why don't you give him a BREAK! Besides... he belongs to my wife!

question: Your BIRTHDAY! Today? Why didn't you tell me?
answer: It's not important. I just had one last year.

question: Well, I'm taking you out to celebrate!
answer: Oh no no! It's no big thing. I'll have another one sometime.

question: I insist. And I want to get you a nice present.
answer: You're so sweet. You don't have to. You gave me a present last year. Those lovely Ginzu knives.

question: Yeah... aren't they great! They last forever. And you can cut right through a shoe with 'em! It's nice to be off the streets... away from all the pain and misery out there.
answer: What's he thinking when he looks at me with that goofy smile...?

question: Boy, does she look stupid in that hat.
answer: If I told him how I really feel, he'd probably fire me. What am I saying? He probably doesn't even know I exist.

question: Laura's incredible. And so smart. Smart enough to recognize that Ginzu knives are the gift of a lifetime. But she never goes out with guys. I wonder why?
answer: I guess I'll just have to wait. But he's married. I could wait forever. Than again... maybe Lana will get hit by a runaway truck. There's always a chance that...

question: But who cares if she... Oh, sorry.
answer: That's alright. I was just rambling.

question: Go ahead...
answer: No, no, really... you first...

question: I insist... please...
answer: Oh, uh... I just wanted to remind you about...

question: ...the Legal Symposium...
answer: ...in Santa Barbara...

question: ...tomorrow... Yeah. I'm driving up in the morning.
answer: He's so cute. He can't even look me in the eye. What is it, Ned? You can tell me.

question: I'm a man, Laura. And all men feel passion at one time or another. Even me.
answer: Really?

question: What would you think of a married man who gave in to those wild, sensual, raging desires?
answer: Oh... wow... golly...

question: What if, for just one crazy moment, he couldn't resist...? He got knocked for a loop and lost control?
answer: Gosh... that might be okay.

question: Hurry up, darling. You'll be late!
answer: It's all taken care of. When do I knock on the door?

question: Wait until I signal you. When I raise the blinds... you knock. Not now!
answer: Oh, later... right... okay.

question: Drive carefully, sweetheart. Say bye- bye to Little Ned. He loves his daddy... don't you Stink Pot?
answer: See you tonight, Junior.

question: What's wrong?
answer: This neighborhood is getting worse all the time! Damn kids stole my engine!

question: Why don't you catch the train to Santa Barbara? It leaves in twenty minutes.
answer: I'll just fly up.

question: No! I mean... you can't. Armed terrorists seized the airport this morning. A plane crashed into the tower... and all the runways are on fire!
answer: Yeah. So?

question: And it's fogged in.
answer: Dammit.

question: For my peace of mind... take the train.
answer: I can't do it. You know how I feel about riding trains.

question: Darling... it's only a short trip.
answer: Yeah... right. A short trip. A short trip to hell in a metal tomb!

question: Just because both your parents died in a train wreck...
answer: And my brother, Jeff...

question: And your brother, Morty...
answer: My two sisters...

question: Right...
answer: My best friend, Al... my dog, Woof... Grandma Rose... and Uncle Lionel. All killed by trains!

question: Coincidence, Ned. Beside... that's the past. They're gone.
answer: Yeah. I guess I can't bring them back by not riding on a train.

question: That's right.
answer: But I just can't get over this stupid nagging fear that...

question: Fear! What about our baby, Ned? I don't want to raise a child in a home filled with fear! But if you can conquer your fear... maybe I can conquer my fear of having a baby with a father who's fearful. Ned... don't let a train kill our child before it's even conceived!
answer: I guess you're right.

question: You're sure now...?
answer: But we'll never make it to the station. By the time a cab gets here...

question: In this crazy world, there's not a whole lot a guy can count on. But when the chips are down, I can always count on you. You risked your life to save mine. A guy can't ask any more from a woman than that. But I saw you shoot him, Lana. In cold blood. I gotta arrest you for murder.
answer: Ned... you wouldn't...

question: Sorry. I'm a cop. I have a job to do.
answer: But... you said it yourself. I saved your life.

question: Don't worry, baby. I know a good lawyer.
answer: What kind of gun did she use?

question: That's a question for the arresting officer. You'll have to ask her attorney.
answer: But aren't you her attorney?

question: Only her husband can answer that. A lovely powder blue dress with a cinch waist, full bodice and a delicately pleated skirt. No comment. I said... NO COMMENT!
answer: Did she eat any of the victim's body parts?

question: Yeah... well I call it a "high-tech lynching of an uppity white housewife." What's this?
answer: Only cell available. They had that serial killer locked up here... you know, the one who talks his victims to death then eats them... Hannibal the Lecturer. But they let him out for a three week tour to publicize his new book.

question: "To Serve Man."
answer: It's a cookbook. And look, look... he autographed it.

question: To Arch... Love to have you for dinner sometime... Hannibal. Very nice.
answer: They're waiting for ya. They didn't want to start without her attorney being present.

question: PFFFTT! Damn moths! This place could use a good exterminator. Can't you get me out of this cage, Ned? I'm goin' buggy in here.
answer: Judge said no bail. Don't worry. Just tell the truth, you'll be fine. Who's gonna handle the interrogation? Okay, okay!... I'll handle it.

question: What're you gonna do... arrest me for primping?
answer: Don't give us a tough time. Just spill it! What were you doing on that train?

question: Well...
answer: As your attorney, I must advise you... you don't have to answer that question. Alright, quit playing games with us! Who put ya up to it? Where'd you get the gun? What's your link with the CIA? Whoa whoa whoa whoa! That's it! I will not tolerate this unwarranted badgering of my client. She'll have her day in court, gentlemen. I want to thank you, Mrs. Ravine, for being so cooperative with these gentlemen. Did you get all that down, Laura. Every word she said?

question: NO!
answer: Yes.

question: NOOOOO!
answer: Yes!

question: NOOOOOOOooooooo!!!
answer: YES! Cappelini pomodoro!

question: What?
answer: Pasta with tomato sauce. Whatsa matta? You don't like Italian?

question: Where's Ned Junior? WHERE IS HE?!
answer: I thought he might like to get out, so I took him to the amusement park.

question: You can't just break into my house, cook my food... borrow my skunk! Leave me alone. Stay out of my face! Out of my neighborhood! Out of my LIFE!
answer: You haven't seen the last of me, Ned. I told you.

question: Mrs. Shady... would you tell us about your son, Max. Was he a... a good boy?
answer: He was the best. And that's not just a mother talking. You can ask anybody.

question: But he got into trouble once in awhile... like all kids do?
answer: Well, you know, pranks. Little jokes and things. But he was so cute. I have pictures! Here. This is when he set the cat on fire... Oh... but the cat deserved it.

question: And what, uh... what are these...?
answer: Marshmallows. He just loved to toast marshmallows over a roaring cat. Burned on the outside... all soft in the middle. And right here... this was taken on the day he left the priesthood to join the Green Berets.

question: Why that shouldn't even be in there! It's his rotten little half-brother. Stinkin' little pecker... he never was any good... Oh! I didn't like these neo-Nazi boys. They were all so fussy and persnickety about everything. Heil this and heil that. Oh look... here's Max with his chainsaw. He loved to go to the national park and cut down those giant old trees. It made him feel so patriotic. You know, if he hadn't been such a successful criminal... I think he would have been a lumberjack. But now he'll never be anything! Not since... ...that woman, your wife, pulled the trigger and put my little Max in his grave!
answer: Mrs. Shady! Do not POINT your finger in my courtroom. It's discourteous, impolite and disrespectful.

question: Don't you tell me what to do with my finger! It's been more places than you've ever dreamed of!
answer: Sit down!

question: Mrs. Ravine... would you please tell the court... what were you doing on that train?
answer: I saw Max Shady at the station... saw him get on board. I knew he'd made threats to kill you and mutilate your reproductive organs... ...so I got on the train too... so I could warn you.

question: Do you want to have children?
answer: Someday. With the right man.

question: But you couldn't have children if my... ...were... ...and, uh...
answer: It would be difficult.

question: So you followed him, knowing you had to protect me... your husband... your best friend... the man you love... the future father of your children.
answer: Something like that.

question: And when you saw that maniac standing in the vestibule, waiting to pulverize my pee-pee... you pulled the gun and fired and fired and FIRED!
answer: And fired and fired and fired and fired and fired and fired and fired... ...and fired and fired and fired.

question: So... you did it. Ya beat the rap.
answer: No thanks to you.

question: Hey... I knew he'd spring ya.
answer: You didn't lift a finger, Frank. You let me take all the heat.

question: Heeeee-eeey... what could I do?
answer: You were gonna let me rot in the slammer... never say a thing.

question: Look... you're out... free. Now we're together. That's what counts. We can try again! Forget triple indemnity. We'll whack him and split three mil.
answer: I'm not splitting anything, Frank. And you know too much.

question: Come on, Lana. You're not gonna shoot me.
answer: You're right. Maybe I'll just screw you to death.

question: I... hate... SALESMEN!
answer: I know it's been a tough ordeal... with the trial and everything. Tell you what... let's take a trip.

question: A trip?
answer: Yeah. Just the two of us.

question: I like that. Just you and me... all alone. I'll start packing.
answer: Great. Listen... I got something to take care of. I'll be back in awhile.

question: Great. Listen... I got something to take care of. I'll be back in awhile.
answer: Who is it?

question: I just want to talk.
answer: Why didn't you say so? Would you like a drink?

question: No thanks. I'm driving.
answer: Then let's get to the point! So what's your problem, tough guy?

question: Stay away from my life, my wife, my home and my pets! I'm taking Lana on a vacation and when I come back, I don't ever want to see your face again!
answer: A VACATION! She doesn't deserve a VACATION! She's a brat! A bad girl! She always was and always will be!

question: What are you talking about? You don't know anything about Lana?
answer: I know EVERYTHING!

question: How do you know her? Who is she to you? TELL ME! Who is she!
answer: She's your wife!

question: Who is she!?
answer: She's my sister!

question: Liar! Who is she?
answer: She's your wife!

question: WHO IS SHE!
answer: She's my sister! She's your wife... AND my sister! She was spoiled rotten! She stole everything I ever had. Everything! Including him.

question: Him? Who, him?
answer: Dwayne. The boy's gym teacher. He was older. So mature... so strong. He smelled like dirty sweat socks and old basketballs. And he was all mine. For awhile. But Lana wasn't satisfied with her own things. She had to have mine too. She took it all... my makeup, my sweaters, my shoes, my underwear...

question: You wore the same clothes?
answer: We were identical twins.

question: What're you talking about? You two don't look anything alike.
answer: Not anymore. One day I caught her stealing my lavender eye shadow and she smashed my face in with a shovel. I had fifty-three operations. When the doctors were finished with me... I looked like THIS! I'm ugly. UGLY!

question: You're beautiful.
answer: Don't lie to me.

question: They did a terrific job!
answer: I look in the mirror. I can SEE!

question: But... you're gorgeous!
answer: Tell that to Dwayne. When he saw my face, he left me for HER... because she looked more like me than I did! First she stole my looks... then she stole the only man who ever loved me! But I found a way to get even. The best revenge possible. Destroy her marriage!

question: That's why you did all this? Seduced me... harrassed me... the tape... the flowers... the phone calls...
answer: You been hangin' out with Dick Tracy, haven't ya?

question: It won't work. Lana loves me.
answer: It doesn't matter. I'm blackmailing her for everything she's worth. She murdered that greasy auto mechanic. I saw her do it.

question: Lana killed Frank Kelbo?
answer: Kelbo! His name was Kelbo?

question: Yeah. Why? Did he burn you on car repairs too?
answer: Dwayne's name was Kelbo. He had a son. Frankie Kelbo.

question: The pieces of the puzzle were falling into place and I didn't like the picture they were making. If Lana really killed Frank Kelbo, then I had misjudged her by a mile. Sure... he was a lousy mechanic. But murder? It was all starting to give me a headache bigger than the national deficit. Lana?
answer: Ned! I'm glad you're here. I have so much to tell you.

question: Come on in. I'll make some tea. Grab a chair.
answer: Thanks... I brought my own.

question: So... what have you got?
answer: A lottery ticket and a laundry receipt. I found them in the pocket of that suit you wore the night you were working under cover with a client. You remember that night, don't ya Ned? Then it hit me. Lottery starts with L-O. Laundry starts with L-A. L- O... L-A. Lola. Don't sweat it. It's the way a woman's mind works.

question: How about Ovaltine?
answer: Fine. Then I remembered you told me some guy named Frank had been working on your wife's car for two months. You with me so far?

question: I'm way ahead of you.
answer: Well back it up. You probably took a wrong turn. Remember your insurance policy... the one we couldn't find? I started thinking, who else had access to it beside you and me? The answer came up... Lana. And since she's a woman, it's probably hidden right here.

question: So that's where she hid the Oreos.
answer: Ned, Lana wasn't trying to save your life when she shot Max Shady. She and Frank were plotting to kill you and collect on your insurance policy. But she shot the wrong guy.

question: That's the craziest thing I ever heard.
answer: Don't you see... Frank was going to let her take the fall. So she murdered him and tried to make it look like suicide. That's when I realized there was a connection between Lola and Lana...

question: Yeah... they're sisters. Twin sisters.
answer: Well, hang on to your jock strap, Ned. There's more. Not only is Frank's father Dwayne Kelbo, notoriously amorous gym teacher and Lola Cain's former lover... Frank's mother is Helen Shady. Max and Frank are half-brothers who never met. Your lovely wife, Lana, murdered both of Helen Shady's sons.

question: This is so unbelievable.
answer: And you haven't even heard my story. He turned into a monster. And that's when I left him. I just couldn't...

question: That damn faucet keeps turning on all by itself. I'll go check it.
answer: Okay. I'll make the Ovaltine.
